import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: Analysis Comparison Modernization and Dependency Theories
text:
This report reflected on the Solow model of economic growth, exploring its significant insights and limitations. It highlights the model‚Äôs emphasis on capital accumulation, labor, and technological progress as key drivers of growth, while also addressing its shortcomings, such as the exogeneity of technological progress and its limited consideration of trade, inequality, and human capital. By integrating academic readings, this work provides a nuanced critique of the model‚Äôs theoretical and practical relevance.


 Back to top

title: Analysis Comparison Modernization and Dependency Theories
text:
This project had critically explored the contrasting perspectives of the Stages of Growth (‚Äúmodernization‚Äù) and Dependency schools of thought regarding economic development. It examined the historical, social, and political contexts that shaped each theory, highlighting how these foundations inform their differing understandings of development processes. The analysis also delves into their core arguments and policy recommendations, drawing attention to the unique implications of each perspective for global economic strategies.

title: Fruit Basket Project
text:
This project was developed during an 8-week introduction to JavaScript course offered by Girls Code First. Throughout the course, I gained proficiency in JavaScript fundamentals and collaborated on a group project covering various topics, including:

Conditional logical and functions.
Arrays and loops.
JavaScript for websites: DOM part 1.
JavaScript for websites: DOM part 2.
Project Initiation.
Building your app.
Project Presentation.

Our final pair, a fruit shop basket, was completed within a 2-week deadline.
In this project, a interactive shopping experience was created. Upon entering the interface, users are greeted by their name and prompted to give an item they would like to purchase. If an item is unavailable, an apology message is displayed. Furthermore, the shop dynamically calculates the contents of the user‚Äôs basket.

title: SQL Project
text:
This project was developed during an 8-week course introducing SQL by Girls Code First. Through this course, I acquired fundamental SQL skills and completed an individual assignment covering various topics, including:

SQL coding and database management techniques.
Data analysis.
Analyzing data from complex structures.
Data manipulation with SQL programming language.
Data management using SQL coding techniques.
Database design and data visualisation.
Project presentation.


  

For my project, I designed a database focused on restaurant order management. This involved implementing foreign and primary keys and creating an Entity-Relationship (EER) diagram.

title: Product Proposal
text:
This project consisted of group and individual elements.
Within the group side we agreed on a product idea and found a dataset related to our product idea, we had to pitch our product in the form of a video presentation which is embedded within the first page of our pdf of our individual report. This had to be an application for students with finance, innovation and entriprise elements.
Within the individual side we had to write the main technicialities about our pitch such as the data analysis, the gap within the market, our customers and how we‚Äôll sell our product. We could have shared elements within the group, however we‚Äôd to have our own touches too within the assignment.
Below are the main snipets of code that aided our teamsdecisions for identifying the gap within the market:

Importing Data and Intial Analysis

Code
# Encode categorical variables using one-hot encoding
data_encoded = pd.get_dummies(df, columns=['category', 'purpose'], drop_first=True)




Code
#convert date columns into date time
df["start_date"] = pd.to_datetime(df["start_date"], errors="coerce")
df["end_date"] = pd.to_datetime(df["end_date"], errors="coerce")




Code
# Handle missing values by dropping rows with missing 'start' or 'stop' and filling 'purpose' with 'unknown'
df.dropna(subset=['start', 'stop'], inplace=True)
df['purpose'] = df['purpose'].fillna("Unknown") 




Code
# Create a new column for trip date
df["date"] = df["start_date"].dt.date




Code
# Ensure the dataset is sorted by date
df = df.sort_values('start_date')
df.set_index('start_date', inplace=True)

Code
# Plot trip frequency over time
plt.figure(figsize=(11, 7))
sns.lineplot(x=df["date"].value_counts().sort_index().index,
             y=df["date"].value_counts().sort_index().values, marker="o")
plt.xlabel("date")
plt.ylabel("Number of Trips")
plt.title("Uber Trips Over Time")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()











Code
# Top 10 most common pickup and drop-off locations
top_pickups = df["start"].value_counts().head(10)
top_dropoffs = df["stop"].value_counts().head(10)

fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(9, 3))

sns.barplot(x=top_pickups.values, y=top_pickups.index, ax=axes[0], palette="Blues_r", hue=top_pickups.index, dodge=False)  
axes[0].set_title("Top 10 Pickup Locations")
axes[0].set_xlabel("Number of Trips")
axes[0].legend([],[], frameon=False)  
sns.barplot(x=top_dropoffs.values, y=top_dropoffs.index, ax=axes[1], palette="Greens_r", hue=top_dropoffs.index, dodge=False)
axes[1].set_title("Top 10 Drop-off Locations")
axes[1].set_xlabel("Number of Trips")
axes[1].legend([],[], frameon=False) 

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()











Code
# Plotted count of trips by purpose
trip_purpose_counts = df["purpose"].value_counts()
plt.figure(figsize=(9, 5))
sns.barplot(x=trip_purpose_counts.index, y=trip_purpose_counts.values, hue=trip_purpose_counts.index, palette="Oranges", legend=False) 
plt.xlabel("Purpose of Trip")
plt.ylabel("Number of Trips")
plt.title("Trip Purpose Distribution")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()

#Main purpose isn't known but second is a meeting which could be relative to commuting with commuting having little, below we see it has the highest average distance by purpose, which backs up our product in relation a student carpooling application which would aid in their commute.











Code
# Plot average trip distance by purpose
avg_miles_purpose = df.groupby("purpose")["miles"].mean().sort_values()
plt.figure(figsize=(9, 5))
sns.barplot(x=avg_miles_purpose.index, y=avg_miles_purpose.values, hue=avg_miles_purpose.index, dodge=False, palette="Blues", legend=False)  
plt.xlabel("Purpose of Trip")
plt.ylabel("Average Miles Traveled")
plt.title("Average Trip Distance by Purpose")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()











Code
# Hourly trip analysis of the day
df["hour"] = df.index.hour
plt.figure(figsize=(9, 5))
sns.countplot(x=df["hour"], hue=df["hour"], dodge=False, palette="coolwarm", legend=False) 
plt.xlabel("Hour of the Day")
plt.ylabel("Number of Trips")
plt.title("Trips by Hour of the Day")
plt.show()
#hours align similarly with college hours.











Code
# Category-wise trip distribution
plt.figure(figsize=(9, 5))
sns.countplot(x=df["category"], hue=df["category"], palette="viridis", legend=False)
plt.xlabel("Trip Category")
plt.ylabel("Number of Trips")
plt.title("Business vs Personal Trips")
plt.show()

title: Botswana‚Äôs Economic Transformation through mineral wealth
text:
This group project examined how Botswana successfully leveraged its mineral wealth‚Äîespecially diamonds to transform from one of the world‚Äôs poorest nations into a stable, middle-income economy. It highlights the government‚Äôs effective resource management, investments in social services, and infrastructure development.
The study also explores the risks of overreliance on diamonds and the rise of synthetic alternatives, emphasizing Botswana‚Äôs strategic shift toward economic diversification. Through initiatives like Vision 2036 and the Economic Reform and Transformation Plan, Botswana is promoting growth in tourism, agriculture, and manufacturing to build a more resilient and inclusive economy.


 Back to top

title: Analysis of the Impact of Technological Change and Shifting Consumer Behaviour on the Global Automobile Industry
text:
This assignment involved exploring how advancements in technology and evolving consumer preferences influence the global automobile industry‚Äôs structure, strategies, and market dynamics.
